fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Existence: Consider the map \begin {split}\psi \colon &\mathbb {F}[x]\to \Bbbk \\ &q(x)\mapsto q(\alpha )\end {split} Let M=\ker (\psi ). Then \mathbb {F}(\alpha )=\mathop {\textrm {Im}}\nolimits (\psi )\cong \mathbb {F}[x]/M, which implies M is a maximal ideal. Since \mathbb {F}[x] is a principal ideal domain, there exists a p(x) such that M=(p(x)). There is only one way to turn p(x) into a monic polynomial, m_{\alpha }(x)=c\cdot p(x), for some c\in \mathbb {F}^{\times }. The polynomial m_{\alpha }(x) is irreducible since the ideal it generates is maximal.

Uniqueness: Let p(x)\in \mathbb {F}[x] be any polynomial with \alpha as a root p(\alpha )=0. Then p(x)\in M, so p(x)=m_{\alpha }(x)q(x) for some q(x). If p(x) is irreducible, q(x) must be a constant polynomial equal to a unit. If p(x) is also monic, then q(x)=1 and therefore p(x)=m_{\alpha }(x). Hence m_{\alpha }(x) is unique.
